abstract.text: We search for the J P C = 0 −− and 1 +− light tetraquark states with masses up to 2.46 GeV/c 2 in Υ(1S) and Υ(2S) decays with data samples of (102 ± 2) million and (158 ± 4) million events, respectively, collected with the Belle detector.
No significant signals are observed in any of the studied production modes, and 90% credibility level (C.L.) upper limits on their branching fractions in Υ(1S) and Υ(2S) decays are obtained.

The inclusive branching fractions of the Υ(1S) and Υ(2S) decays into final states with f 1 (1285) are measured to be B(Υ(1S) → f 1 (1285) + anything) = (46 ± 28(stat.) ± 13(syst.)) × 10 −4 and B(Υ(2S) → f 1 (1285) + anything) = (22 ± 15(stat.) ± 6.3(syst.)) × 10 −4 .

The measured χ b2 → J/ψ + anything branching fraction is measured to be (1.50 ± 0.34(stat.) ± 0.22(syst.)) × 10 −3 , and 90% C.L. upper limits for the χ b0,b1 → J/ψ + anything branching fractions are found to be 2.3 × 10 −3 and 1.1 × 10 −3 , respectively.
For B(χ b1 → ω + anything), the branching fraction is measured to be (4.9 ± 1.3(stat.) ± 0.6(syst.)) × 10 −2 .
All results reported here are the first measurements for these modes.

body_text.text: I. INTRODUCTION

In the past decade, many experiments, both at lepton and hadron colliders, have reported evidence for a large number of particles having properties that can not be readily explained within the framework of the expected heavy quarkonium states [1,2].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Among them, the X(3872) [3], the Z c (3900) [4,5], the X(3940) [6], the Y (4260) [7,8], the Z(4430) [9], the Z b (10610) and the Z b (10650) [10], are generally interpreted as possible tetraquark candidates with exotic properties.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In the low-mass region, the Dalitz analysis of the decay D 0 → π + π − π 0 [11] indicates the existence of a state decaying into a ρπ final state with exotic quantum numbers J P C = 0 −− [12] at a mass of ≈ 1865 MeV/c 2 , which cannot be composed of a quark-antiquark pair in the conventional quark model [13,14].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: If such a resonance exists, it might be a hybrid or a tetraquark state [15].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The authors of Ref.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: [16] calculated the masses of such exotic four-quark states with J P C = 0 −− and 1 +− in Laplace sum rules (LSR) and finite-energy sum rules (FESR) using tetraquark-like currents.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In the scalar channel, both LSR and FESR gave consistent mass predictions of a tetraquark state with a mass of (1.66±0.14) GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: This numerical result favors the tetraquark interpretation of the possible ρπ dominance in the D 0 decays.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In the vector channel, the authors also conservatively estimated the mass of a tetraquark state to be in the mass region 1.18 − 1.43 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Although the masses have been calculated, the width and couplings to any final states were not predicted.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Very recently, the Belle Collaboration reported the search for the J P C = 0 −− glueball (G 0 −− ) in the production modes Υ(1S, 2S) → χ c1 + G 0 −− , Υ(1S, 2S) → f 1 (1285) + G 0 −− , χ b1 → J/ψ + G 0 −− , and χ b1 → ω + G 0 −− with data samples of (102 ± 2) million Υ(1S) and (158 ± 4) million Υ(2S) events [17].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The masses of the putative glueballs were fixed at 2.800, 3.810, and 4.330 GeV/c 2 , as predicted from quantum chromodynamics (QCD) sum rules [18] and distinct bottom-up holographic models of QCD [19].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Considering the kinematical constraints and the conservation of the quantum numbers J P C , the production modes for glueball searches are also suitable for searches for the aforementioned light tetraquark states with J P C = 0 −− and 1 +− , denoted collectively as X tetra .
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In this paper, we utilize the low-mass recoil spectra of the χ c1 , f 1 (1285), J/ψ, and ω in bottomonium decays to search for X tetra signals in the modes Υ(1S, 2S) → χ c1 + X tetra , Υ(1S, 2S) → f 1 (1285) + X tetra , χ b1 → J/ψ + X tetra , and χ b1 → ω + X tetra [17].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Since the X tetra properties are unknown, we report our investigation for different assumed values for the X tetra mass and width.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: As byproducts of the X tetra search, we measure the inclusive f 1 (1285) production in Υ(1S, 2S), J/ψ production in χ bJ (J = 0, 1, 2), and ω production in χ b1 decays.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: II.
THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

This analysis utilizes the Belle Υ(1S) and Υ(2S) data samples with a total luminosity of 5.74 and 24.91 fb −1 , respectively, corresponding to (102 ± 2) × 10 6 Υ(1S) and (158 ± 4) × 10 6 Υ(2S) events [20].
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: An 89.45 fb −1 data sample collected at √ s = 10.52 GeV is used to estimate the possible irreducible contributions from continuum (e + e − → qq, where q ∈ {u, d, s, c}).
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: Here, √ s is the center-of-mass (C.M.) energy of the colliding e + e − system.
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: The data were collected with the Belle detector [21,22] operated at the KEKB asymmetric-energy e + e − collider [23,24].
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: Large Monte Carlo (MC) samples of all of the investigated tetraquark modes are generated with EVT-GEN [25] and simulated with a GEANT3-based [26] model for the detector response to determine the signal line-shapes and efficiencies.
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: The angular distribution for the decay Υ(2S) → γχ bJ is simulated assuming a pure E1 transition (dN/d cos θ γ ∝ 1 + α cos 2 θ γ with α = 1, − 1 3 , 1 13 for J = 0, 1, 2, respectively [27], where θ γ is the polar angle of the Υ(2S) radiative photon in the e + e − C.M. frame); a phase space model in EVTGEN is used for the χ bJ decays.
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: We use the phase space model for other decays as well.
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: Note that the X tetra inclusive decays are modelled using PYTHIA [28].
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: Inclusive Υ(1S) and Υ(2S) MC samples, produced using PYTHIA with four times the total numbers of Υ(1S, 2S) events of the data, are used to identify possible backgrounds showing peak distributions from Υ(1S) and Υ(2S) decays.
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: The Belle detector is a large solid-angle magnetic spectrometer that consists of a silicon vertex detector, a 50-layer central drift chamber, an array of aerogel threshold Cherenkov counters, a barrel-like arrangement of time-of-flight scintillation counters, and an electromagnetic calorimeter comprised of CsI(Tl) crystals located inside a superconducting solenoid coil that provides a 1.5 T magnetic field.
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: An iron flux-return yoke instrumented with resistive plate chambers located outside the coil is used to detect K 0 L mesons and to identify muons.
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

body_text.text: A detailed description of the Belle detector can be found in Refs.
body_text.section: II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR
II. THE DATA SAMPLE AND BELLE DETECTOR

MEASUREMENTS OF χ bJ → J/ψ + anything
The χ bJ is identified through the decay Υ(2S) → γχ bJ .

body_text.section: IV. MEASUREMENTS OF χ bJ → J/ψ + anything

body_text.text: After requiring the lepton-pair mass to be within the J/ψ signal region, Figs. 5 (a-c) show the distributions of the Υ(2S) radiative photon energy in the e + e − C.M. frame from MC simulated Υ(2S) → γχ bJ , χ bJ → J/ψ + anything decays, where each χ bJ signal shape is described by the convolution of a BW function with a Novosibirsk [29] function.
body_text.section: IV. MEASUREMENTS OF χ bJ → J/ψ + anything

body_text.text: Based on the fitted results, the efficiencies are (23.87 ± 0.42)%, (32.21 ± 0.53)%, and (22.96 ± 0.39)% for χ b0 , χ b1 and χ b2 , respectively.
body_text.section: IV. MEASUREMENTS OF χ bJ → J/ψ + anything

body_text.text: As shown in Fig. 6 of the spectrum of the Υ(2S) radiative photon energy in the C.M. frame, a clear χ b2 signal may be observed.
body_text.section: IV. MEASUREMENTS OF χ bJ → J/ψ + anything

body_text.text: After all selection requirements, no backgrounds showing peak distributions are found in the distribution estimated from J/ψ mass sideband data, nor in the continuum production in the χ bJ signal regions, in agreement with the expectation from the Υ(2S) generic MC samples.
body_text.section: IV. MEASUREMENTS OF χ bJ → J/ψ + anything

body_text.text: An unbinned extended maximum-likelihood fit to the spectrum is performed to extract the signal and background yields in the Υ(2S) data samples.
body_text.section: IV. MEASUREMENTS OF χ bJ → J/ψ + anything

body_text.text: In the fit, the probability density function (PDF) of each χ bJ signal is a BW function convolved with a Novosibirsk function with all the parameters free; for the background PDF, a third-order Chebyshev polynomial function is adopted.
body_text.section: IV. MEASUREMENTS OF χ bJ → J/ψ + anything

body_text.text: The fit yields 243 ± 101, 269 ± 120, and 462 ± 105 events for the χ b0 , χ b1 , and χ b2 signals, respectively, in the Υ(2S) data sample.
body_text.section: IV. MEASUREMENTS OF χ bJ → J/ψ + anything

body_text.text: The statistical significances of the χ b0 , χ b1 and χ b2 signals are estimated to be 1.5σ, 1.1σ and 3.5σ, from the differences of the logarithmic likelihoods, −2 ln(L 0 /L max ), where L 0 and L max are the likelihoods of the fits without and with a signal component, respectively (taking the number of degrees of freedom in each fit into account).

body_text.text: V. MEASUREMENTS OF χ b1 → ω + anything
Candidate ω mesons are reconstructed via π + π − π 0 .

body_text.section: V. MEASUREMENTS OF χ b1 → ω + anything

body_text.section: V. MEASUREMENTS OF χ b1 → ω + anything

body_text.text: The ω signal shape is described by a Voigtian function with the values of the parameters fixed to those from the fit to MC-simulated signals; a second-order Chebyshev polynomial background shape is used for the χ b1 decay backgrounds in addition to the normalized χ b1 sideband.
body_text.section: V. MEASUREMENTS OF χ b1 → ω + anything

body_text.text: The fitted ω signal yield is 51054 ± 12943 and the estimated statistical significance is 4.1σ.
body_text.section: V. MEASUREMENTS OF χ b1 → ω + anything

body_text.text: Hence, the branching fraction for χ b1 → ω + anything is measured for the first time to be B(χ b1 → ω + anything) = (4.9 ± 1.3(stat.) ± 0.6(syst.)) × 10 −2 .

body_text.text: VI.
SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

We generate a large number of MC samples for Υ(1S, 2S) → χ c1 + X tetra , Υ(1S, 2S) → f 1 (1285) + X tetra , χ b1 → J/ψ + X tetra , and χ b1 → ω + X tetra with X tetra masses varying from 1.16 to 2.46 GeV/c 2 in steps of 0.10 GeV/c 2 and widths varying from 0.0 to 0.3 GeV in steps of 0.1 GeV, using the same decay modes as in Ref.

body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: In the channels analyzed below, Υ(1S, 2S) → χ c1 + X tetra , Υ(1S, 2S) → f 1 (1285) + X tetra , χ b1 → J/ψ + X tetra , and χ b1 → ω + X tetra , we search for the X tetra signals in the recoil mass spectra of the χ c1 , f 1 (1285), J/ψ, and ω, respectively, with X tetra widths between 0.0 and 0.3 GeV in steps of 0.1 GeV.

body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: There are no evident signals for any of the X tetra states at any of the masses.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: In the entire region of study, the most significant signal is observed at an X tetra mass of 2.46 (2.26) GeV/c 2 and width of 0.3 (0.0) GeV with a statistical significance of 1.4σ (0.6σ) in Υ(1S) (Υ(2S)) data.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: Since the number of selected signal candidate events is small, we obtain the 90% C.L. upper limit of the signal yield (N UL ) at each X tetra mass point by using the frequentist approach [30] implemented in the POLE (Poissonian limit estimator) program [31], where each mass region is selected to contain 95% of the signal according to MC simulations, the number of observed signal events is counted directly, and the number of expected background events is estimated from the sum of the normalized χ c1 sideband and continuum contributions.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: The systematic uncertainties discussed below are taken into account.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: The calculated upper limits on the numbers of signal events (N UL ) and branching fraction (B UL ) for each X tetra state with X tetra masses from 1.16 to 2.46 GeV/c 2 and widths from 0.0 to 0.3 GeV in Υ(1S, 2S) data are listed in Table II, together with the reconstruction efficiencies (ε) and the systematic uncertainties (σ syst ).
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: The results are displayed graphically in Fig. 11. For Υ(1S, 2S) → f 1 (1285) + X tetra , f 1 (1285) candidates are reconstructed via ηπ + π − , η → γγ.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: Figure 12 shows the recoil mass spectra of the f 1 (1285) in Υ(1S, 2S) data, together with the backgrounds from the normalized f 1 (1285) sideband and the normalized continuum contributions.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: No evident X tetra signals are seen.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: An unbinned extended maximum-likelihood fit repeated with X tetra masses from 1.46 to 2.46 GeV/c 2 in steps of 0.10 GeV/c 2 , and with X tetra widths from 0.0 to 0.3 GeV in steps of 0.1 GeV, is applied to the recoil mass spectra.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: The signal shape of each X tetra signal is described with a BW function convolved with a Novosibirsk function, where all parameter values are fixed to those from the fit to the MC-simulated signals.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: Since no backgrounds showing peak distributions are found, a second-order Chebyshev polynomial shape is used for the backgrounds.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: The fit result for the X tetra signal with its mass fixed at 1.66 GeV/c 2 (a theoretically predicted mass for a scalar tetraquark state [16]) and width fixed at 0.10 GeV is shown in Fig. 12. The fit yields 1.7±4.7 (−0.3±9.8) events for the X tetra signals in the Υ(1S) (Υ(2S)) data sample.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: In the whole mass region of interest, the most significant signal is observed at an X tetra mass of 2.26 (2.16) GeV/c 2 and width of 0.0 (0.3) GeV with a statistical significance of 1.1σ (1.8σ) in Υ(1S) (Υ(2S)) data.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: For χ b1 → J/ψ + X tetra , the χ b1 is identified through the decay Υ(2S) → γχ b1 .
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: Figure 13 shows the recoil mass spectrum of γJ/ψ in Υ(2S) data, together with the background estimated from the normalized J/ψ sideband and the normalized continuum contributions.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: No evident X tetra signal is observed.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: An unbinned extended maximum-likelihood fit is applied to the γJ/ψ recoil mass spectrum.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: The result of the fit with the X tetra mass fixed at 1.66 GeV/c 2 and width fixed at 0.10 GeV is shown in Fig. 13. This fit yields 8.9 ± 5.8 X tetra signal events.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: In the entire region of study, the most significant signal is observed at an X tetra mass of 1.76 GeV/c 2 and width of 0.1 GeV, with a statistical significance of 2.8σ.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: For χ b1 → ω + X tetra , ω candidates are reconstructed via π + π − π 0 , π 0 → γγ.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: Figure 14 shows the recoil mass spectrum of γω for events in the ω signal region, along with the backgrounds from the normalized ω sideband and the normalized continuum contributions.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: No evident X tetra signal is observed.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: An unbinned extended maximum-likelihood fit is applied to the γω recoil mass spectrum.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: The result of the fit including the X tetra signal with its mass fixed at 1.66 GeV/c 2 and width fixed at 0.10 GeV is shown in Fig. 14.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: This fit yields −7.8 ± 9.1 X tetra signal events.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: In the entire region of study, the most significant signal is observed at an X tetra mass of 2.26 GeV/c 2 and width of 0.1 GeV, with a statistical significance of 2.2σ.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: Considering the yields for Υ(1S, 2S) → f 1 (1285) + X tetra , χ b1 → J/ψ + X tetra and χ b1 →  ω + X tetra are very small, we determine the 90% C.L. upper limits on the X tetra signal yields (N UL ) for M(X tetra ) < 1.46 GeV/c 2 following the procedure in Ref.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: [31] as described above for Υ(1S, 2S) → χ c1 + X tetra , and for M(X tetra ) > 1.46 GeV/c 2 using the same method as described for χ b0,b1 → J/ψ + anything.
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: Here, the systematic errors have been taken into account in the determination of N U L .
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: The calculated upper limits on the numbers of signal events (N UL ) and branching fraction (B UL ) for Υ(1S, 2S) → f 1 (1285) + X tetra , χ b1 → J/ψ + X tetra and χ b1 → ω + X tetra with X tetra masses from 1.16 to 2.46 GeV/c 2 and widths from 0.0 to 0.3 GeV are listed in Table II, together with the reconstruction efficiencies (ε) and the systematic uncertainties (σ syst ).
body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.section: VI. SEARCH FOR X tetra IN Υ(1S), Υ(2S), AND χ b1 DECAYS

body_text.text: VII.
SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES
Most of the systematic errors in the branching fraction measurements are the same as in Ref.
body_text.section: VII. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: [17], including tracking reconstruction, photon reconstruction, particle identification, trigger efficiency, the branching fractions of the intermediate states, and the total numbers of Υ(1S) and Υ(2S) events; the notable exception is the dominant systematic error from the fit uncertainty.
body_text.section: VII. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: By changing the order of the background polynomial and the range of the fit, the model-dependent relative difference in the signal yields (or the upper limits for those modes with statistically insignificant branching fractions) is obtained; this is taken as the systematic error due to the uncertainty of the fit.
body_text.section: VII. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The estimation of the continuum contributions in the f 1 (1285) inclusive production processes assumes a 1/s 2 dependence.
body_text.section: VII. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: The analysis is repeated assuming a 1/s or 1/s 3 dependence and the largest change in the fitted f 1 (1285) signal yield is taken as a systematic uncertainty.
body_text.section: VII. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: Assuming that all of these systematic-error sources are independent, the total systematic errors are summed in quadrature and listed in Table II for all the studied modes for each hypothesized X tetra mass.
body_text.section: VII. SYSTEMATIC UNCERTAINTIES

body_text.text: VIII.
SUMMARY

In summary, utilizing the recoil mass spectra of the χ c1 , f 1 (1285), J/ψ, and ω in the channels Υ(1S, 2S) → χ c1 + G 0 −− , Υ(1S, 2S) → f 1 (1285) + G 0 −− , χ b1 → J/ψ + G 0 −− , and χ b1 → ω + G 0 −− [17], respectively, we report the first search for the light tetraquark states predicted with a mass of 1.66 ± 0.14 GeV/c 2 and J P C = 0 −− , and with a mass in the region 1.18-1.43 GeV/c 2 and J P C = 1 +− [16].
body_text.section: VIII. SUMMARY

body_text.text: No evident signal is found below 3 GeV/c 2 in the above processes and 90% C.L. upper limits are set on the branching fractions.
body_text.section: VIII. SUMMARY

body_text.text: Figures 11 and 15 show the upper limits on the branching fractions as a function of the tetraquark masses.
body_text.section: VIII. SUMMARY

body_text.text: In addition, as byproducts of the search, we measure the inclusive f 1 (1285) production in Υ(1S, 2S), J/ψ production in χ bJ (J = 0, 1, 2), and ω production in χ b1 .
body_text.section: VIII. SUMMARY

body_text.text: The corresponding branching fractions are measured for the first time to be B(Υ(1S) → f 1 (1285) + anything) = (46 ± 28(stat.) ± 13(syst.)) × 10 −4 , B(Υ(2S) → f 1 (1285) + anything) = (22 ± 15(stat.) ± 6.3(syst.)) × 10 −4 , B(χ b2 → J/ψ + anything) = (1.50 ± 0.34(stat.) ± 0.22(syst.)) × 10 −3 , and B(χ b1 → ω + anything) = (4.9 ± 1.3(stat.) ± 0.6(syst.)) × 10 −2 , and the 90% C.L. upper limits on the branching fractions B(χ b0 → J/ψ + anything) < 2.3 × 10 −3 and B(χ b1 → J/ψ + anything) < 1.1 × 10 −3 are determined for the first time.
body_text.section: VIII. SUMMARY

body_text.text: IX.
body_text.section: VIII. SUMMARY

body_text.text: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS TABLE II: Summary of the upper limits for Υ(1S, 2S) → χ c1 + X tetra , f 1 (1285) + X tetra , and χ b1 → J/ψ + X tetra , ω + X tetra under different assumptions of X tetra mass (m in GeV/c 2 ) and width (Γ in GeV), where N UL is the upper limit on the number of signal events taking into account systematic errors, ε is the reconstruction efficiency, σ syst is the total relative systematic uncertainty on the branching fraction and B UL is the 90% C.L. upper limit on the branching fraction.
body_text.section: VIII. SUMMARY
